message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of lower back pain that improves with physical activity and normal reflexes suggest mechanical lower back pain. Radiograph sacroiliac joint is the most appropriate next step to look for structural abnormalities such as fractures or arthritis. ESR is not specific for lower back pain and a slit-lamp examination is not indicated for this presentation. An MRI sacroiliac joint may be considered if the radiograph is negative and clinical suspicion of an inflammatory cause remains high.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ankylosing spondylitis, which typically affects the sacroiliac joints. Radiograph is the most appropriate next test to confirm the diagnosis. ESR can be elevated in ankylosing spondylitis, but it is not diagnostic. MRI sacroiliac joint can also be used to diagnose ankylosing spondylitis, but radiograph is typically the first test for initial evaluation. Slit-lamp examination is not relevant to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest mechanical low back pain, which is usually treated with conservative management. The most appropriate next test would be a radiograph of the sacroiliac joint to rule out any structural abnormalities. ESR is not specific enough to diagnose mechanical low back pain, and an MRI would be costly and unnecessary at this time. A slit-lamp examination would be used to evaluate the eyes and is not relevant to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ankylosing spondylitis or a similar inflammatory joint disease. The best initial test would be a radiograph of the sacroiliac joint to look for bony changes indicative of ankylosing spondylitis. ESR may also be elevated in ankylosing spondylitis, but it’s a non-specific lab test. MRI may be helpful for confirming the diagnosis, but it’s more expensive compared to an X-ray. A slit-lamp examination would not be helpful in this case as there are no ocular symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ankylosing spondylitis, which is characterized by lower back pain, decreased chest expansion, and decreased spinal range of motion. Radiograph of the sacroiliac joint is the most appropriate test to confirm this diagnosis. ESR may be elevated in ankylosing spondylitis but this is not the most appropriate initial test. MRI sacroiliac joint may be used to evaluate disease activity or progression, but it is not the best initial test. Slit-lamp examination is not relevant to this patient’s symptoms.

Radiograph sacroiliac joint would help identify any structural abnormality in the sacroiliac joint, which is a common cause of mechanical low back pain. ESR is not specific enough for mechanical low back pain. MRI sacroiliac joint is more sensitive but not necessary as a first-line test. Slit-lamp examination is not relevant for this patient's symptoms.

Radiograph of the sacroiliac joint is the most appropriate next test. ESR is not specific and can be elevated in a variety of conditions. MRI may be ordered if radiograph is negative or inconclusive. Slit-lamp examination is not relevant to this patient's complaint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest ankylosing spondylitis, which is typically seen in young males and can cause lower back pain that improves with physical activity. ESR can be elevated in ankylosing spondylitis but is not specific enough for diagnosis. MRI can show sacroiliitis but is expensive and not always necessary for diagnosis. Radiograph of the sacroiliac joint is the most appropriate initial test to evaluate for ankylosing spondylitis. Slit-lamp examination is not necessary for this condition.

The most appropriate next test would be a radiograph of the sacroiliac joint, which can help confirm the diagnosis. ESR may be elevated in ankylosing spondylitis, but it is not the most appropriate next test. MRI may be used to evaluate for inflammation in the sacroiliac joint, but it is not typically the initial test. Slit-lamp examination is used to evaluate for uveitis, which can occur in ankylosing spondylitis, but it is not the most appropriate next test for this patient.

Radiograph of the sacroiliac joint is the initial test for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis. ESR can be used for monitoring the disease activity while MRI is used for detecting early inflammatory changes before radiographic changes occur.
